content.description: Major Depressive Disorder (MDD) is characterized by one or more major depressive episodes involving persistent low mood and/or anhedonia with associated cognitive, neurovegetative, and psychomotor changes causing clinically significant distress or impairment. Episodes are not attributable to a substance or another medical condition and are not better explained by other primary psychiatric disorders.
content.diagnostic_criteria: A. ≥5 symptoms during the same 2-week period, representing a change from previous functioning, with at least one being depressed mood or markedly diminished interest/pleasure: (1) depressed mood; (2) markedly diminished interest/pleasure; (3) significant weight/appetite change; (4) insomnia/hypersomnia; (5) psychomotor agitation/retardation; (6) fatigue/loss of energy; (7) feelings of worthlessness or excessive/inappropriate guilt; (8) diminished ability to think/concentrate or indecisiveness; (9) recurrent thoughts of death, suicidal ideation, plan, or attempt. B. Symptoms cause distress/impairment. C. Not attributable to a substance or another medical condition. D. Not better explained by schizoaffective/schizophrenia spectrum disorders. E. No history of manic or hypomanic episode.
content.prevalence: 12-month prevalence ~7% adults; higher in females. Substantial global burden with high recurrence and disability.
content.age_of_onset: Peak onset late adolescence to mid-20s; can occur across the lifespan.
content.prognosis: Course ranges from single episode to recurrent/chronic. Early treatment, full remission, and maintenance reduce relapse/recurrence and suicide risk. Comorbidity (anxiety, substance use, medical illness) and psychosocial stress worsen outcomes.

circuitry: Dysfunction in fronto-limbic networks (prefrontal cortex, anterior cingulate, amygdala, hippocampus) affecting emotion regulation and cognitive control.
Default mode network hyperconnectivity with reduced task-positive network engagement; altered reward circuitry in ventral striatum.
neurochemistry: Glutamate/GABA imbalance; neurotrophic factors (e.g., BDNF) reduced during episodes; HPA-axis dysregulation and inflammatory cytokine elevations.
neurobiology.genetic_environmental: Polygenic vulnerability interacting with adverse life events, chronic stress, sleep disruption, and medical comorbidity.

history_psychosocial: Episode timeline, triggers, prior episodes/treatments, suicidality/self-harm, psychosis, catatonia, peripartum or seasonal pattern.
Function across school/work/home; substance use; trauma history; sleep, pain, and medical comorbidities.
medical_assessment: Screen labs when indicated: CBC (anemia), CMP, TSH/free T4; B12/folate, HbA1c, lipids; pregnancy test if applicable.
Consider sleep apnea screening, ECG if cardiac risk/antipsychotic or TCA use.
standardized_measures: PHQ-9 or HAM-D for severity/monitoring; GAD-7 for anxiety.
C-SSRS for suicide risk; MoCA if cognitive complaints prominent.
risk_stratification: Urgent evaluation/higher level of care for active suicidal intent/plan, psychosis, catatonia, severe dehydration/weight loss, or inability to care for self.
differential_diagnosis: Bipolar depression (screen for past hypomania/mania), persistent depressive disorder, adjustment disorder, grief, substance/medication-induced depression, neurocognitive disorder, hypothyroidism and other medical causes.
evaluation.team_and_process: Collaborative care among primary care, psychiatry, psychotherapy, and when needed sleep/pain specialists; include family/supports (with consent) for safety and adherence.

psychotic_possible: Mood-congruent or incongruent delusions/hallucinations in severe cases

severity_levels.mild: Few symptoms beyond diagnostic threshold, minor impairment.
severity_levels.moderate: Symptoms and impairment between mild and severe.
severity_levels.severe: Many symptoms, marked impairment; psychotic features or high suicide risk may be present.

biological: Chronic medical illness, pain, sleep disorders
psychological: High neuroticism, perfectionism, negative attributional style
environmental: Substance use, shift work, circadian disruption

impact_on_life.school_work: Absenteeism, presenteeism, reduced productivity and errors.
impact_on_life.medical: Poor adherence to treatments, worsened outcomes, increased healthcare utilization.

comorbidities: Anxiety disorders (GAD, panic, social anxiety, PTSD)

psychotherapy: Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) — behavioral activation, cognitive restructuring, relapse prevention.
Interpersonal Psychotherapy (IPT) — role disputes/transitions, grief, social support.
Behavioral Activation (BA) — structured activity scheduling and reward re-engagement.
Acceptance & Commitment Therapy (ACT) or Mindfulness-Based CBT as adjuncts.
Family/couples therapy when relational stressors contribute.
medications: First-line antidepressants: SSRIs (sertraline, escitalopram, fluoxetine, paroxetine, citalopram).
SNRIs (venlafaxine, desvenlafaxine, duloxetine, levomilnacipran) — consider if pain/fatigue prominent; monitor blood pressure.
Bupropion — energizing, fewer sexual side effects; avoid in seizure/eating disorders.
Mirtazapine — helpful for insomnia, low appetite/weight loss.
Tricyclics (e.g., nortriptyline) and MAOIs — effective but second/third-line due to side-effect and interaction profiles.

Augmentation for partial response: aripiprazole, brexpiprazole, quetiapine XR; lithium (suicide risk reduction); liothyronine (T3) in selected cases; buspirone or bupropion combo; psychostimulants/modafinil for residual fatigue (specialist-guided).
Peripartum: weigh maternal-fetal risks/benefits; sertraline often favored; coordinate with obstetrics.
Geriatrics: start low/go slow; monitor hyponatremia; consider QTc with citalopram; watch drug interactions.
neuromodulation: Electroconvulsive Therapy (ECT) for severe, psychotic, catatonic, or treatment-resistant depression, or urgent suicidality.
Repetitive Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation (rTMS) for treatment-resistant cases.
Ketamine/esketamine (under REMS/clinic protocols) for treatment-resistant depression or acute suicidal ideation.
Vagus Nerve Stimulation (VNS) in highly refractory chronic depression (specialist-guided).
lifestyle_interventions: Sleep hygiene and circadian regularity; CBT-I when indicated.
Regular aerobic activity and structured daily routines.
Nutrition supporting metabolic health; limit alcohol/cannabis.
Social rhythm stabilization; problem-solving for stressors; digital mood tracking.
care_coordination: Collaborative care linking primary care and behavioral health.
Safety planning for suicidality; means restriction counseling.
Monitor side effects and labs (e.g., metabolic panels for SGAs, lithium levels/renal/thyroid when used).

treatment_goals: Achieve full symptom remission and functional recovery.
Prevent relapse/recurrence with continuation and maintenance strategies.
Reduce suicide risk and address comorbidities.
Improve quality of life, sleep, and role functioning.
missed_diagnosis_factors: Presenting chiefly with somatic complaints (pain, fatigue, GI) in primary care.
Assuming symptoms are normal grief, burnout, or personality without assessing criteria and impairment.
Unrecognized bipolar spectrum — inadequate screening for past hypomania leading to antidepressant monotherapy risks.
overdiagnosis_factors: Transient stress reactions or adjustment disorder labeled as MDD without full criteria/duration.
Bereavement or cultural/religious mourning incorrectly pathologized.
Cognitive effects of medications/medical illness mistaken for depression without mood/anhedonia.
warning_signs: Escalating suicidal ideation, planning, or rehearsal.
New psychotic features, catatonia, or failure to maintain nutrition/hydration.
self_help_strategies: Daily routine with scheduled pleasant activities and gradual activation.
Sleep regularity; limit long naps; consistent wake time.
Peer support, problem-solving steps for stressors, and values-aligned goals.
Use reminders/pill organizers; attend follow-ups and share safety plan with supports.

adolescence: Irritable mood more prominent; school decline and social withdrawal; coordinate school supports and family engagement.
adulthood: Work impairment, parenting stress; integrate workplace accommodations and couples/family interventions when relevant.
older_adults: More somatic/cognitive symptoms; higher medical comorbidity; favor SSRIs with safer profiles; monitor hyponatremia and falls.
peripartum: Onset during pregnancy or within 4 weeks postpartum; screen for safety, bonding difficulties; coordinate obstetrics/pediatrics.

real_life_examples: A 17-year-old with declining grades, irritability, insomnia, and anhedonia responds to CBT-A plus sertraline and sleep regularization.
A 38-year-old with recurrent depression and chronic pain improves with duloxetine, behavioral activation, and PT-guided exercise.
A 72-year-old with severe psychotic depression achieves remission after an ECT course followed by maintenance sertraline and psychotherapy.
content.when_to_seek_help: Immediate help for suicidal thoughts/intent, psychosis, catatonia, or inability to care for self. Prompt evaluation for persistent low mood/anhedonia ≥2 weeks with impairment, especially if recurrent or with medical comorbidity.

positive_factors: Early, adequate dose/duration of treatment and adherence
Strong social support and engagement in psychotherapy
challenging_factors: Comorbid anxiety/substance use, chronic medical illness, or personality pathology
Treatment resistance, residual symptoms, or rapid relapse after remission
Ongoing psychosocial adversity or unstable housing/employment
